content:
#### What you should be familiar with before taking this lesson

- [End behavior of polynomials](/math/algebra2/polynomial-functions/polynomial-end-behavior/a/end-behavior-of-polynomials)
- [Zeros of polynomials and their graphs](/math/algebra2/polynomial-functions/zeros-of-polynomials-and-their-graphs/a/zeros-of-polynomials-and-their-graphs)
- [Graphs of polynomials](/math/algebra2/polynomial-functions/graphs-of-polynomials/a/graphs-of-polynomials)

#### What you will do in this lesson

Now that we have learned about the features of the graphs of polynomial functions, let's put that knowledge to use!  

In this set of problems, the equations of the polynomials are not completely given. This way, they force us to focus on a specific feature of the polynomial's graph.

Good luck!

options.explanation:
In this case, we do not know the specific values of $a$, $b$, and $c$, and so we will not be able to determine end behavior, $x$-intercepts, or the intervals over which the polynomial is positive or negative.  

We do, however, know that the constant term is $2$.  This will be the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y=ax^3+bx^2+cx+2$, because when we input $x=0$, we get $y=2$. 

So the $y$-intercept of the graph of the function is $(0,2)$.  The only graph that has this feature is graph $C$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane. It is a cubic graph passing through the y-axis at (two, zero).

options.content:
**1*) Which of the following could be the graph of $y=ax^3+bx^2+cx+2$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are real numbers?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane. It is a cubic graph passing through the y-axis at (zero, zero).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/099605f2eab8d9b4197856ad14c576858d5e1010)

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane. It is a cubic graph passing through the y-axis at (negative two, zero).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d057a6a9f5f2fbd837852662f91de12d054c2fa7)

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane. It is a cubic graph passing through the y-axis at (two, zero).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9ecbc6f9c0bf74f295b957c2046c0b3b4d8d819f)

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane. It is a cubic graph passing through the y-axis at (zero, zero).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/53f81b246ee346801870c5ffcc0489003ea3b824)

options.explanation:
In this case, we do not know the polynomial $p(x)$, and so we will not be able to determine the $x$- or $y$-intercepts, or the intervals over which the polynomial is positive or negative.  

We can, however, determine the function's end behavior.  Since the degree of $p(x)$ is less than the degree of $-2x^5$, we know that $-2x^5$ must be the leading term of the polynomial!

So the end behavior of $y=-2x^5+p(x)$ will be the same as the end behavior of the monomial $-2x^5$. 

Since the degree of $\greenD{-2}x^\blueD5$ is odd $(\blueD 5)$ and the leading coefficient is negative $(\greenD{-2})$, the end behavior will be as follows:

>As $x\rightarrow +\infty$, $y\rightarrow -\infty$ and as $x\rightarrow -\infty$, $y\rightarrow +\infty$.   

This feature is only seen in graph $B$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that crosses the x-axis three times and crosses the x-axis once as a cubic function.

options.content:
**2*) Which of the following could be the graph of $y=-2x^5+p(x)$, where $p(x)$ is a fourth degree polynomial?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that crosses the x-axis twice and touches the x-axis once.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/515916b50b0db2769f221e2a5e5ad01cdd1542d1)

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that crosses the x-axis three times and crosses the x-axis once as a cubic function.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b68751f0b30c3236ca1ea440178f33f97dff9c8)

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that crosses the x-axis twice and crosses the x-axis once as a cubic function.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e2700dd0c5b3e68d43086b32fe1fe3c53c98f79b)

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that crosses the x-axis twice and touches the x-axis once.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3e66657517d79d4b792c517b2b0fc5c16e93844f)

options.explanation:
We do not know the value of $k$, and so we cannot make a claim regarding the $y$-intercept, the end behavior, or the positive and negative intervals of the function's graph.  

We do, however, know that $2$ is a zero of even multiplicity.  This means that the graph of the function must touch the $x$-axis at $(2,0)$.

We also know that $-1$ is a zero of odd multiplicity.  This means that the graph of the function must cross the $x$-axis at $(-1,0)$.  

The graphs that have these features are $A$ and $D$.

[[☃ image 1]] $\qquad $[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that crosses the x-axis at (negative one, zero) and touches the x-axis at (two, zero).
A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that touches the x-axis at (two, zero) and crosses (negative one, zero) like a cubic function.

options.content:
**3*) Which of the following could be the graph of $y=k(x-2)^m(x+1)^n$, where $k$ is a real number, $m$ is an even integer, and $n$ is an odd integer?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that touches the x-axis at (negative one, zero) and (two, zero).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/fe17ff57f951c58cb1632e35a1861dc01341d448)

![A polynomial is graphed on an x y coordinate plane that touches the x-axis at (two, zero) and crosses (negative one, zero) like a cubic function.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/61c94f179a8eee34ba9d85d205070296b3e88336)
